newsitem.title: USA: US Sen D'Amato hopes to act on banking reform bill.
newsitem.headline: US Sen D'Amato hopes to act on banking reform bill.

text.p: Senate Banking Committee chairman Alfonse D'Amato on Thursday said he wants his panel to act on a financial services reform measure that would allow banks to conduct up to 25 percent of their business in non- financial activities.

The measure, introduced by Rep. Marge Roukema, a New Jersey Republican, and Rep. Bruce Vento, a Minnesota Democrat, is a compromise to financial modernization proposals introduced by D'Amato and in the House by Rep. Richard Baker, which would impose virtually no limits on bank commerical activities.
"I think the answer is we are first going to move the Roukema bill, which I think is very important so that the dual banking system is preserved," D'Amato, a New York Republican, told reporters.
The Roukema bill, backed by an alliance of financial service trade groups, would allow a bank to do up to 25 percent of its business in non-financial activities.
A measure introduced by House Banking Committee Chairman Jim Leach, an Iowa Republican, would allow only minimal combinations among banks and commercial firms.
D'Amato expressed doubts about Congress being able to pass his broader financial reform measure.

"I'd love to see that take place, but the realities are can you get sufficient support?" the lawmaker said. "Many of major banking institutions who were supportive of that have now been less inclined to be supportive so I don't know whether that is something that can be accomplished."
